Key Arguments: The bill undermines freedom of speech by creating a division between politicians, journalists, and educational institutions versus ordinary citizens.
The legislation imposes excessive fines and limitations on regular Australians' ability to express viewpoints.
The code of conduct is overly stringent and applies to the entire industry without relief or alternatives.
Determining truth is complex and evolving; past authoritative facts have been proven false.
The bill targets not only false information but also true information deemed misleading, suppressing healthy discourse.
Delegating legislative power to private entities undermines democratic processes and freedom of political communication.
The bill threatens digital platform providers and ordinary users with penalties and burdens.
Independent media organizations face reputational risks, while government-approved journalists are exempt from certain requirements.
Notable Quotes: This biased division undermines the democratic principles on which our nation is built and disproportionately harms ordinary individuals.
The task of accurately determining what is true or false is virtually impossible.
By censoring information seen as 'misleading,' this bill suppresses healthy discourse and undermines the value of diverse viewpoints.
Delegating legislative power to private entities not directly accountable to Parliament undermines the democratic process.
